articles.headline: White House Scales Back a Mortgage Relief Plan
articles.snippet: The goal will be to modify the mortgages of homeowners facing foreclosure so that a monthly loan payment is no higher than 38 percent of a borrower’s monthly income.
articles.abstract: The goal will be to modify the mortgages of homeowners facing foreclosure so that a monthly loan payment is no higher than 38 percent of a borrower’s monthly income.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration is backing away from proposals to have the government refinance a broad swath of homeowners who face foreclosure after taking out subprime mortgages and other high-risk loans over the last few years.

articles.headline: Oil Prices Drop to 20-Month Low
articles.snippet: Oil prices fell below $60 a barrel despite growing indications that OPEC producers have been trimming output.
articles.abstract: Oil prices fell below $60 a barrel despite growing indications that OPEC producers have been trimming output.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil prices fell to their lowest level in 20 months on Tuesday, despite efforts by the OPEC cartel to stem the slide, as weak economic growth continued to reduce consumption around the world.

articles.headline: Google Uses Searches to Track Flu’s Spread
articles.snippet: Google is tracking the ebb and flow of Web queries like “flu symptoms” in an effort to identify outbreaks.
articles.abstract: Google is tracking the ebb and flow of Web queries like “flu symptoms” in an effort to identify outbreaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  There is a new common symptom of the flu, in addition to the usual aches, coughs, fevers and sore throats. Turns out a lot of ailing Americans enter phrases like “flu symptoms” into Google and other search engines before they call their doctors.

articles.headline: Law Firms Feel Strain of Layoffs and Cutbacks
articles.snippet: Some established firms have collapsed outright, others are laying off by the hundreds, and others still are seeking mergers with larger firms to try and weather the storm.
articles.abstract: Some established firms have collapsed outright, others are laying off by the hundreds, and others still are seeking mergers with larger firms to try and weather the storm.
articles.lead_paragraph: You know things are bad when even lawyers are getting laid off.

articles.headline: Veterans’ Families Seek Aid for Caregiver Role
articles.snippet: Veterans groups are pursuing legislation to allow families of soldiers with traumatic injuries to be paid for caregiving.
articles.abstract: Veterans groups are pursuing legislation to allow families of soldiers with traumatic injuries to be paid for caregiving.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tracy Keil met her husband, Matt, in August 2005 between his first and second tours of duty in Iraq. They married in January 2007. Six weeks later, Staff Sergeant Keil was shot in the neck while on patrol in Ramadi, Iraq, and rendered a quadriplegic.

articles.headline: G.M., Once a Powerhouse, Pleads for Bailout
articles.snippet: Shares in G.M. sank to their lowest point in 65 years, the day after it revealed its ability to survive is in substantial doubt because it may run out of money by the end of the year.
articles.abstract: Shares in G.M. sank to their lowest point in 65 years, the day after it revealed its ability to survive is in substantial doubt because it may run out of money by the end of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Just two months after celebrating its 100th birthday, General Motors is facing the grim prognosis that it may not survive to see another year unless it is rescued by a bailout from the federal government.

articles.headline: Negotiating Better Terms for Mortgage
articles.snippet: Banks may be willing to negotiate with borrowers who are current with their payments, even if they aren’t promoting it aggressively.
articles.abstract: Banks may be willing to negotiate with borrowers who are current with their payments, even if they aren’t promoting it aggressively.
articles.lead_paragraph: You don’t need to be behind on your mortgage payments to ask for a better deal from your bank.

articles.headline: After U.S. Breakthrough, Europe Looks in Mirror
articles.snippet: Many Europeans are asking themselves if there could be a French, British, German or Italian Obama.
articles.abstract: Many Europeans are asking themselves if there could be a French, British, German or Italian Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  In the general European euphoria over the election of Barack Obama, there is the beginning of self-reflection about Europe’s own troubles with racial integration. Many are asking if there could be a French, British, German or Italian Obama, and everyone knows the answer is no, not anytime soon.

articles.headline: Buying Binge Slams to Halt
articles.snippet: With Wall Street edging back from the brink, a consumer confidence crisis has become the biggest short-term economic issue.
articles.abstract: With Wall Street edging back from the brink, a consumer confidence crisis has become the biggest short-term economic issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just as one crisis of confidence may be ending, another may be coming.

articles.headline: U.S. Aid Worker Slain in Pakistan
articles.snippet: The worker in a program to bring development to a lawless region of Pakistan was assassinated in his car, in an act of violence highlighting the difficulty in stabilizing the volatile region.
articles.abstract: The worker in a program to bring development to a lawless region of Pakistan was assassinated in his car, in an act of violence highlighting the difficulty in stabilizing the volatile region.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — For the six months he helped execute the “hearts and minds” outreach of the United States on one of the most dangerous front lines of the American battle against militants, Stephen D. Vance had to balance a strategic mission with nearly daily concerns about his personal safety.

articles.headline: U.S. Shifts Focus in Credit Bailout to the Consumer
articles.snippet: Henry M. Paulson Jr. is hoping to put in place a major new lending program run by the Fed and aimed at unlocking the frozen consumer credit market.
articles.abstract: Henry M. Paulson Jr. is hoping to put in place a major new lending program run by the Fed and aimed at unlocking the frozen consumer credit market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department on Wednesday officially abandoned the original strategy behind its $700 billion effort to rescue the financial system, as administration officials acknowledged that banks and financial institutions were as unwilling as ever to lend to consumers.
